verdict.summary: InvalidOperationException is thrown when a method call is invalid for the current object state. Common in LINQ operations on empty sequences and improper use of dependency injection. Fix by validating state before operations.

dead_ends.action: Catching InvalidOperationException and retrying the same operation without changing state
dead_ends.why_fails: The object state that caused the exception has not changed, so the retry will throw the same exception in an infinite loop or until another failure occurs

dead_ends.action: Replacing First() with FirstOrDefault() everywhere without checking for default values
dead_ends.why_fails: Silently returns null or default(T) which causes NullReferenceException or logic errors downstream instead of surfacing the real problem of an empty sequence

workarounds.action: Use FirstOrDefault/SingleOrDefault with explicit null checks
workarounds.how: Replace .First() with .FirstOrDefault() and add an explicit null/default check: var item = collection.FirstOrDefault(); if (item is null) { /* handle empty case */ }

workarounds.action: Validate object state or collection contents before calling the operation
workarounds.how: Use .Any() to check if a sequence has elements before calling .First()/.Single(), or check object state properties before performing state-dependent operations

leads_to.condition: when FirstOrDefault returns null and the result is used without null check
when invalid state causes downstream argument validation failures

preceded_by.condition: when EF Core query returns unexpected results due to tracking issues
when database query fails silently and code tries to operate on empty result set

frequently_confused_with.distinction: InvalidOperationException means the object exists but the operation is not valid for its current state; NullReferenceException means the object does not exist at all
